markdownRemark.html:
Researches about theory (R)

  1. Classification of Variables

    Variables can be classified in the following categories:

    • Qualitative

      • Nominal: Differentiates between characteristics based only on their names or categories and other classifications they belong to. There is no clear order between each value.

        Can be useful to measure for example the nationality of the students of an statistics classroom.

      • Ordinal: Unlike nominal this one allows for a rank order by which the data can be ordered.

        Can be useful to measure data consisting of a spectrum of values like opinions.

    • Quantitative

      • Interval: Is used when hte distance between attributes does have a meaning.

        Can be useful to measure data like temperature.

      • Ratio: Allows for a meaningful absolute value.

        Is useful for measuring data like mass, length, duration, etc.

    Sources:

    • Wikipedia: Levels of Measurement
    • Conjointly: Levels of Measurement

  1. Most common configuration of data repositories in the real world

    Let's start by giving some definitions:

    Online Transaction Processing: Are systems characterised by a large number of short online transactions, mainly focused on maintaining data integrity.

    Data Warehouse: are central repositories that collect data from multiple sources.

    Data Marts: are a subsets of the data warehouse that collects information oriented to a specific business line or team.

    Online Analytical Processing: Are systems characterized by their low volume of transactions, mainly focused on giving an answer to multidimensional analysis.

    Sources:

    • Wikipedia: OLTP
    • Wikipedia: Data Warehouse
    • Wikipedia: Data Marts
    • Wikipedia: OLAP

  1. How to obtain the online algorithm for arithmetic mean

    Starting from the naive algorithm we now the arithmetic mean is defined as

    xˉn=Σnxin \bar{x}_n = \frac{\Sigma_n x_i}{n}xˉn​=nΣn​xi​​

    that we could rewrite as

    nxˉn=Σnxi n \bar{x}_n = \Sigma_n x_inxˉn​=Σn​xi​

    if we wanted to find xˉ\bar{x}xˉ at the n+1n+1n+1 moment

    (n+1)xˉn+1=Σn+1xi→ (n+1) \bar{x}_{n+1} = \Sigma_{n+1} x_i \to(n+1)xˉn+1​=Σn+1​xi​→ (n+1)xˉn+1=xn+1+Σnxi (n+1) \bar{x}_{n+1} = x_{n+1} + \Sigma_{n} x_i(n+1)xˉn+1​=xn+1​+Σn​xi​ (n+1)xˉn+1=xn+1+nxˉn (n+1) \bar{x}_{n+1} = x_{n+1} + n \bar{x}_n (n+1)xˉn+1​=xn+1​+nxˉn​ xˉn+1=xn+1+nxˉnn+1 \bar{x}_{n+1} = \frac{ x_{n+1} + n \bar{x}_n }{n+1}xˉn+1​=n+1xn+1​+nxˉn​​ xˉn+1=xn+1+(n+1−1)xˉnn+1 \bar{x}_{n+1} = \frac{ x_{n+1} + (n+1-1) \bar{x}_n }{n+1}xˉn+1​=n+1xn+1​+(n+1−1)xˉn​​ xˉn+1=xn+1+(n+1)xˉn−xˉnn+1 \bar{x}_{n+1} = \frac{ x_{n+1} + (n+1) \bar{x}_n - \bar{x}_n}{n+1}xˉn+1​=n+1xn+1​+(n+1)xˉn​−xˉn​​ xˉn+1=xˉn+xn+1−xˉnn+1 \bar{x}_{n+1} = \bar{x}_n + \frac{ x_{n+1} - \bar{x}_n}{n+1}xˉn+1​=xˉn​+n+1xn+1​−xˉn​​

    thus getting the online algorithm:

    xˉn=xˉn−1+xn−xˉn−1n \bar{x}_{n} = \bar{x}_{n-1} + \frac{ x_{n} - \bar{x}_{n-1}}{n}xˉn​=xˉn−1​+nxn​−xˉn−1​​

    This algorithm is preferred for cases we already know xˉn\bar{x}_nxˉn​ instead of applying the naive formula

    xˉn+1=xn+1+nxˉnn+1 \bar{x}_{n+1} = \frac{ x_{n+1} + n \bar{x}_n }{n+1}xˉn+1​=n+1xn+1​+nxˉn​​

    since computers have limitations when dealing with big decimal point numbers as we'll see later on this paper.

  1. Problems with Naive Formula
class Program
    {
        static float naive(float[] info)
        {
            float sum = 0.0f;
            foreach (float elem in info)
            {
                sum += elem;
            }
            return sum / info.Length;
        }
        static float knuth(float[] info)
        {
            float avg = 0.0f;
            for (int i = 0; i < info.Length; i++)
            {
                avg += ((float)info[i] - avg) / (i + 1);
            }
            return avg;
        }

        static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            float [] data = { ... };
            // the array data contains 98 integers which 
            // its avg = 634142998897.8148

            Console.WriteLine(naive(data)); // 6.3414285E+11
            Console.WriteLine(knuth(data)); // 6.3414305E+11
        }
    }

As shown the naive algorithm is 198897.8148 away from the actual average

C# Project

Researches about applications (RA)

  1. How Floating Point Representation works

    We know any number can be rewritten in scientific notation as for example

    • −0.1=−1E−1- 0.1 = -1E-1−0.1=−1E−1
    • 1000=1E31000 = 1E31000=1E3
    • 234=2.34E2234 = 2.34E2234=2.34E2

    In words we can say

    X=n.mantissa∗10exponent X = n.mantissa * 10^{exponent}X=n.mantissa∗10exponent

    with n being the integer part and the mantissa the decimal.

    This works perfectly when we work in a base 10 numeric system but computers work with binary, meaning our formulas would be

    X=1.mantissa∗2exponent X = 1.mantissa * 2^{exponent}X=1.mantissa∗2exponent 1.mantissa=Xbin2(exponent) 1.mantissa = \frac{X_{bin}}{2^{(exponent)}}1.mantissa=2(exponent)Xbin​​

    Lets try with an example:

    −100010=−0011111010002 - 1000_{10} = - 001111101000_{2}−100010​=−0011111010002​

    In Base 10 is:

    −100010=−1∗102 - 1000_{10} = - 1 * 10^2−100010​=−1∗102

    mean while in binary:

    −11111010002=−1.111101∗29 - 1111101000_{2} = - 1.111101 * 2^9−11111010002​=−1.111101∗29

    With this clear we can introduce the IEEE 745 floating point standard which defines how a given floating point number is stored in computer memory.

    IEEE 745 defines multiple formats depending on the quantity of bits we can use but for simplicity we'll introduce the single precision since is one of the most common now days.

    before we can rewrite our last example using this format we must know that the exponent is encoded adding 126 to the original exponent to allow negative integers.

    so our new formula will be:

    X=(−1)sign∗1.mantissa∗2Exponent−126 X = (-1)^{sign} * 1.mantissa * 2^{Exponent-126}X=(−1)sign∗1.mantissa∗2Exponent−126

    applying it to the example −1.111101∗29- 1.111101 * 2^9−1.111101∗29 this number will be saved as:

    the standard define 2 special cases for the encoded exponent:

    • 00H00_H00H​: is used for subnormal numbers to allow even smaller numbers using a new formula:

      X=(−1)sign∗0.mantissa∗2−126 X = (-1)^{sign} * 0.mantissa * 2^{-126}X=(−1)sign∗0.mantissa∗2−126
    • FFHFF_HFFH​: Is interpreted as Not a Number meaning the value is undefined or unrepresentable.

    With this in mind we can start talking about the limitations of this presentation:

    1. It can't properly handle small numbers, in fact 2−1492^-1492−149 is the smallest number it can represent
    2. Given a big number x this representation wont be able to differentiate x+1 from x.

    Distribution of numbers in a toy floating point system with only three bits for the exponent and mantissa - Cleve Moler

    Sources:

    • GeekForGeek: IEEE Standart 745 Floating Point Numbers
    • Wikipedia: IEEE 745
    • Wikipedia: Single precision float
    • Floating points by Cleve Moler
